comments.commentBody: Seems like a Rubio/Cruz ticket is the Republicans' only hope. Rubio as the smiling face presented to the public and Cruz as the behind-the-scenes badass - similar to the Bush/Cheney alliance.
Guys, it does not matter what people vote for, the goal is to be elected and rule!

I wish people would stop comparing the division within the Republican party as being a problem with both parties.  Democrats do not close down the government or vote 60 plus times to overturn a law (the health care act) or take from the poor and give to the rich!!  So just stop it and check you facts.  Democrats compromised with Reagan and Bush.  It is the far right of the the Republican party that is the problem.   They first catered to the "Fundamental Christian Right", mainly the Conservative Southern Baptist, and then the Tea Party.  This is a problem created by the   "main stream" of the party to win elections.  They thought once in office they could be controlled.   Now the Ultra Fundamentalist and Tea Party have come back to "bite" them.  Be careful what you ask for...

Maybe the Republican Party should reorganize as a third party and run their own candidate? Frankly, I think establishment Republicans could put together a ticket of their own choosing that would have a pretty good chance of winning in November. Rubio, Cruz, or Carson aren't going to win, and if Trump wants to run without the backing of mainstream Republicans, well, there's no law against it. And the GOP is so fractured now, and the Tea Party has moved so far from the center of the GOP that they might just as well declare themselves a separate party, because they are totally unrecognizable as "Republicans."

So, how about a "brave new world" of a three party system? Don't laugh - or go ahead if you must. But if we did have three parties, it would at least bring an end to this "never compromise!" grandstanding nonsense that has had our government in gridlock since the 90's. Because with three parties, they'd have to compromise then or never be able to get anything done. And if they don't get anything done, well, that would be just like it is today - so what's to lose by trying?

replies.commentBody: JimH - Given your naivtee, which is displayed by your belief that Trump "loves" the underdog, I have a bridge I'd like to sell you.

comments.commentBody:
Trump is like an orange topped Evita, ready to sacrifice further fortune to devote himself to uplifting all those left behind. He's driven by his need for love and affection, and very likely by a need to revenge himself against all those in the elite who have snubbed and dismissed him.

Appealing as he does to the bottom 60 per cent, he will probably win the Republican nomination, then pick up many Democrats and independents in the general election.

He is essentially a populist who has said he'll protect the social safety net. Though he's said he'll end Obamacare, he's unlikely to support any attempt by Congress to eliminate it without immediately replacing it with "something better," Trumpcare. He'll gladly use the top one per cent's money to ensure Trumpcare is gold plated.

Melania was probably right when she said "if you run, you will win."

Here's a thought experiment:

Bernie wins the Democratic nomination. Rubio, Cruz or Bush go into the Republican nomination hobbled by a bitter campaign, with the eventual nominee not broadly accepted by the right. Trump and his supporters feel cheated that they were denied the nomination and he goes about campaigning as an independent. Bloomberg steps in as another independent who claims to be the only adult in the room. Who wins in a 4-way race? How would the country accept a President who might win with only 26% or less of the popular vote?

Although the analogy is hardly exact, Ted Cruz "won" Iowa like George W. Bush "won" the presidency in 2000. Other than that, Mr. Cohn's analysis appears right on target.

Polls show Donald J. Trump beating Hillary handily in November. Democrats ignore this at their peril, just as perilously as underestimating The Donald has proven so far.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

replies.commentBody: There's an important difference in the race this year. There is more energized support for Trump than there was for Romney. I think many writers underestimate the anti-establishment appeal that even transcends specific issues for many voters. New Hampshire set turnout records this year and more of that was due to the Republican side. I read that the Democratic vote numbers didn't match up with 2008. Sanders has strong support, but I'd be surprised if he could pull off a general election win. And if Hillary wins the nomination, especially if it seems tainted by any primary or caucus result controversy, there are a lot of progressive Democrats who are really turned off by her. They won't match the voter enthusiasm that Trump has ignited. Trump may put more blue states in play, as well.

comments.commentBody:
So far, Trump's dynamics are similar to Romney's in 2012: there are "surges" in different states, because there are plenty of people who don't like him to go for "generic Republican". Problem is, a "generic Republican" is something that doesn't really exist, so once the field narrows, it is very reasonable that a lot of votes will go to Trump rather than the supposed "consolidated candidate". This may mean that the outcome may be similar to 2012: Trump is the eventual nominee that loses decisively in the general election.

The big difference is that Trump's voters are a lot more passionate about Trump than Romney's supporters were in 2012. I think that the big difference is that Trump runs on a platform, while most other candidates don't, while in 2012 it was completely unclear what Romney ran on. When you run on something as mushy as Romney did, it's far easier to be defined from outside, like Obama did to Romney, than when you have a coherent core.

replies.commentBody: A President Sanders and wife Jane are not likely to want pomp and ceremony, but may welcome members of the 99% to dine with them, enjoy a musical performance, discuss the problems and successes of the day. The Trumps?  and the 99% (us?) Not so much.

I think you're right about Sanders, Raven.  Trump, ironically, would probably be more welcoming than you think.  He'd be living in public housing in this case, so if the "great-unwashed" got mud on the carpet, he wouldn't have to pick up the tab.   Trump:  "Let 'em all in...It's not like i'm paying for it."

comments.commentBody:
After last night's election it appears that a growing number of Americans are looking forward to the Donald and his lovely wife Melania moving into the White House.
My oh my.
Camelot Returns :)

I don't see Rubio picking up many moderate supporters.  He is not "moderate" in any sense of the term, if you listen to him closely.  If Kasich fades, my sense is that many of them will go to Trump (!) or perhaps a few to Jeb!

Marco Rubio will NEVER capture the moderate Republicans like so many dream he can.  His social policies - opposition to abortion in ALL cases (see Debate #1), his opposition to same sex marriage, and his about face on immigration - make his marginal at best.  Most moderate Republicans are fiscally conservative, socially libertarian and environmentally progressive.  He can't carry that vote.

A fascinating conundrum. I had not thought about Kasich's position that way, but as I think about it, the supporting facts to Nate's comment are that Kasich has no money (not a slight problem these days) and his odd "slow down" message certainly does not resonate in *this* campaign season. Maybe in days of yore, but even then George H.W. Bush had "the big mo'". Voters don't want to contemplate their navels.

As you write Nate, this is a very tight, indecisive race, even perhaps on the Democratic side when the future primaries are factored in. I'm not a political historian, but one could exaggerate that never before have voters been so disgruntled and not be far from right.

So I'm thinking that South Carolina is a three or even four way split... or five way split. Rubio has a presence there, as does Cruz, who, as you write, has that evangelical crowd, or some of it. South Carolinians will also like Trump. If Kasich is on the rise, he might find some moderate voters to support him, and Jeb could also have a presence and will probably do so. That's five.

If that five-way split happens in SC, campaigns are going to be noticeably distraught. Claims of a landslide victory with a 1 percent margin will abound.

I agree with many other commenters here: Cohn should go back review Overton's window. There are only hard-right candidates in the leading slots. Kasich, perhaps might qualify as a moderate, but the hard right turn of the GOP forces him to track right. And Trump? The irony is that he is the only one that has ever expressed any socially moderate views, though he is ditching all of them. And Jeb! look at his tax plan -- more .01% friendly than W's and he has the same neocon military advisers as his brother. These are moderates? No. We should all face the fact that there are no moderates in the GOP race, and if a putative one like Kasich wins, the House and Senate will force him to maintain the hardline, out-of-the-mainstream positions (like on abortion, climate change denial, Citizens United, tax bonuses for billionaires) that have dominated their rhetoric to date.

replies.commentBody:
We are in a "hellish landscape, a dystopian nightmare." And, I don't ever watch Fox News. Trillions of dollars in debt. What does that even mean? The mind can't even register that amount of red ink. And, then there is the unprecedented situation with Russia, China, Iran, North Korea and ISIL. Try reading, The Atlantic Council, Brookings Institute, Business Insider, Rand Corp., Epoch Times. We are entering into a time of great civil unrest world wide, and in our own country by the constant drum beat of class and race division - by certain members of the Democratic Party. We are re-positioning troops and military hardware to counter Russian aggression throughout Europe. Putin has positioned missile batteries that as I write this have effectively shut down the air space over Eastern Europe and he is moving more into Crimea along with troops ahead of the talks taking place this week. China has built a rapid deployment army with thousands of tanks and troop transports, not to mention islands in South China Sea and is deploying aircraft and navel craft threatening the largest maritime trade route in the world. Here is just one little scenario:
http://www.businessinsider.com/russia-could-steamroll-into-the-capitals-...
One can also read this on just about any military website and find interviews with the joint chiefs as well as European Commander, General Hodges.
Was that intended as a parody of right-wing thinking?
No, that is reality and a wake up call.

comments.commentBody:
You're falling back on the media's go to line: "tonight’s result means it will take longer for the party to rally around one candidate."

But maybe the party doesn't want to. Maybe the base of the Republican party actually wants Trump. They have been told for 7 years, by the party itself, and by its favored news outlets like Fox, that the U.S. is a hellish landscape, a dystopian nightmare. If you watch Fox for more than half an hour you would think the U.S. is almost on the verge of imminent collapse.

I'm sure the political press and the GOP establishment, what remains of it, see Trump as a disaster. But maybe the GOP base thinks he's just what they need.

replies.commentBody:
Why, Mr. Resor? You probably have heard it before; you merely don't remember. May I suggest you use "Google" to find Radio-Re-Broadcasts from the 1930's.
The familiar Ring will be frightening.

comments.commentBody: If I was running against Trump, I would spend all my ad dollars replaying his New Hampshire victory speech again and again.

I am not sure what Mr. Trump is on any political spectrum other than opportunistic.  I agree with the earlier reader Kate/commenter  that non of the rest are moderates but merely shades of Tea Party Red.  As to the problems this causes the Republicans: Cry me a river.

replies.commentBody: What made Reagan possible was Reagan's treason of negotiating with the Iranians while Carter was president to delay the release of the American embassy hostages in Tehran to the morning of Ronnie's inauguration.

Lets be clear.  The past 30 or so years have made both Trump and Sanders possible.  An ever increasingly insular legislative branch that has no idea what is going on in average households across the country nor really cares.  Presidential politics that promise heaven on earth all the while knowing that what they offer is impossible.   Along with an out of control banking and investment system that has allowed: ".....private banks to control the issue of their currency, first by inflation, then by deflation, the banks and corporations that will grow up around them will deprive the people of all property until their children wake up homeless on the continent their Fathers conquered." To quote Thomas Jefferson.  This is why we have two individuals who are "outsiders" running for office.  The people can distinguish between right and wrong, it is our politicians who have lost their way - hence a 5% approval rating.  And, it doesn't take an ivy league education to be able to do that. Any working man or woman in this country has a better character than 95% of those we elect to run our country.  Congress better take heed to what is happening in this election because they are next.  We gave them 8 years.  Both parties.  They couldn't even agree on what kind of donuts to buy for their endless meetings let alone run the country.  We are fed up and this election cycle proves it.
No kidding.  He also gave them a boatload of arms, the big stiff.

comments.commentBody: Just like Carter made Reagan possible; Obama has made Trump possible.

replies.commentBody: We are berating Donald Trumps business practices?  How about Apple and Mr. Steve Jobs who the President called the greatest man in the world? Apple makes a 40% profit on their Iphones by manufacturing them in China with practically slave labor.  I find that kind of businessman really rather akin to the mill owners who worked children to death during the industrial revolution.  There are no Iphones in this house.  Everyone who owns one has no right to scold Donald Trump.

comments.commentBody:
There's really no reason to wonder why trump is winning the "outside" vote. Year after year the same issues ate brought up and nothing is ever fixed. Personally I like Trumps issue on the H1-b visa and the fact he is a true business man. People bring up the fact that he uses outside labor, least you all forget that's business and you have to compete with competition who are using the same flawed legal system on immigration. Of course if he just hired hard working Americans he wouldn't have an empire, he used the system to his advantage.... Which is "winning". He knows the system and it's loop holes. Common sense at this point.

Americans should come first, not second. It's very clear that having career politician's in office is absolutely not working.Well that's my opinion....

The pundits are incorrigible. Cohn talks of "a Republican with broader appeal, like Mr. Rubio." Wht broad appeal has Rubio shown? He never did well in the polls, rose slightly with huge media promotion, and lost that bubble in the last debate, which the Times has documented was not a fluke. The more exposure Rubio has the clearer his scripting becomes. He could be the least promising Republican candidate.

replies.commentBody:
It's a bit hard to tell at this point which candidates are running for the vice presidency, because a lot of the candidates were gearing up their campaign under the assumption that Bush will be the eventual nominee, and that he'll need to pick a sidekick to do better among the group. However, Trump's rise threw a wrench into these plans.

I think that Cruz, Rubio and Kasich were running for VP under Bush. I think that Christie, Bush and Carson were running for their own. I think that Christie thinks that quitting now will harm him in his own state, Bush is irrational and still has money, and Carson doesn't care.

comments.commentBody: I am still trying to figure out which of these candidates is running for the vice presidency.
Mr. Trump has surprised the Republician establishment. New day for the party.

Statisticlly meaningless differences between the third place finishers notwithstanding... when will NYT stop falling for meaningless shorthand labels?
To say someone is 'conservative' or 'liberal' doesn't mean anything.

We see some describing themselves as 'very conservative', or 'somewhat conservaative'. Convenient, but meaningless.

Can you be fiscally conservative and socially liberal? How can you be in favor of social programs without being fiscally responsible enough to find a solid way to finance them? Where does one draw the line in applying a single word label?

Or does 'conservative' mean anti-abortion? What if you're opposed to abortion, but even more opposed to government intervention in our bedrooms, or in our relationships with our doctors or clergy? Where is that line drawn?

Does anyone ask serious questions of these clowns, anymore? Clearly the talking heads do not; does the old grey lady?
The real question now is whether a sufficient number of American voters are angry and spiteful enough to spit into the common soup we all eat out of and elect Donald Trump. I believe there are.

replies.commentBody: He is not saying anything because he and his organization know that the second he does the news media which is slanted toward "progressive socialist ideology' will eviscerate him.  The people voting for Trump understand this and it is ok with them.  I want to hear more from the times on Sanders policies and how viable they really are.  And, for the record this household has one life long Democrat in it who is seriously considering either Trump or Kasich, who ever gets the nod.  We are not in any way going to vote for a Socialist.  Period. And I suspect there are many people who feel as we do on both tickets.

comments.commentBody: Trump has a remarkable talent for the jugular and for pithy slogans.  He refuses to say what he would do to solve the nation's problems, however.  I just hope that GOP primary voters came to realize during this infernally long primary process that Trump has no idea about what to do to solve our problems.

Jeb Bush spent more than $600 per vote received.
In what world is he viable????
